body: I am unable to reproduce this in my app using `4.next`.

Hi @ADmad - thanks looking into it!

I've added a demo_project with a Test that demonstrates the problem. Running `composer test` shows an error but shouldn't.

https://github.com/swiffer/demo_project

https://github.com/swiffer/demo_project/blob/master/tests/TestCase/Controller/ArticlesControllerTest.php

```
1) App\Test\TestCase\Controller\ArticlesControllerText::testSQL
Failed asserting that two arrays are equal.

--- Expected
+++ Actual
@@ @@
 Array (
     0 => Array (
-        0 => '1'
-        1 => 'My first Article'
-        2 => '2017-03-23 17:13:02'
-        3 => '2017-03-23 17:13:02'
+        'id' => '1'
+        'name' => 'My first Article'
+        'created' => '2017-03-23 17:13:02'
+        'modified' => '2017-03-23 17:13:02'
     )
-        0 => '2'
-        1 => 'My second Article'
-        2 => '2017-03-23 17:13:02'
-        3 => '2017-03-23 17:13:02'
+        'id' => '2'
+        'name' => 'My second Article'
+        'created' => '2017-03-23 17:13:02'
     )
 )
```
The actual usecase is different. I had the query log enabled for debugging another problem and some tests running fine previously started to fail.

Thanks for the test case @swiffer.

The issue is caused by `BufferedStatement::rowCount()` which fetches records as associative arrays 

https://github.com/cakephp/cakephp/blob/818eddcd6b96060b64447fab667de26b126fc3ee/src/Database/Statement/BufferedStatement.php#L258-L265

It manifests only with logging enabled because `LoggingStatement::execute()` calls `rowCount()`
https://github.com/cakephp/cakephp/blob/818eddcd6b96060b64447fab667de26b126fc3ee/src/Database/Log/LoggingStatement.php#L67

So essentially when used buffered statement calling `rowCount()` before doing a fetch has the potential to cause unexpected results as it fetches the rows before a `fetchAll()` call is explicitly made.

The fix would be to change `LoggingStatement` to not call `rowCount()`.

This issue mostly likely exists in 4.0 and probably even 3.x too.

Another solution which covers all use cases is if the buffer is already populated `BufferedStatement::fetchAll()` should check the fetch type and either convert the records in buffer to required type or re-fetch records.
Yes, possible I've seen this before
This might be the best test case of 2020.

The SQL Panel of the DebugKit Plugin is showing the same information, isn't it?

I think it's working just fine there

issue.title: Fix query LoggingStatement prematurely fetching records.

repository.name: cakephp
repository.description: CakePHP: The Rapid Development Framework for PHP - Official Repository

issue.body:
LoggingStatement::execute() calling rowCount() for SELECT queries
caused records do be always fetched as associative arrays when using
buffered results. This meant that calling fetchAll() later with
type FETCH_TYPE_NUM for e.g. returned unexpected results.

Fixes #14676
